Direct hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over carbon-supported Ru catalysts: A computational study Miroslav Rubeš a Junjie He b Petr Nachtigall a Ota Bludský a b ⁎ a Department of Physical and Macromolecular Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Charles University in Prague, Hlavova 2030, CZ-128 40, Prague 2, Czech Republic Department of Physical and Macromolecular Chemistry Faculty of Science Charles University in Prague Hlavova 2030 Prague 6 CZ-128 Czech Republic b Institute of Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic, Flemingovo nám. 2, Prague 6, 162 10, Czech Republic Institute of Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic Flemingovo nám. 2 Prague 6 162 10 Czech Republic ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over graphene-supported Ru nanoparticles was investigated by means of periodic DFT calculations to propose a mechanism for the direct deoxygenation (DDO) pathway. The calculated interaction energies and activation barriers for the CO scission on bare particle models of Ru/C catalysts are in good agreement with previous computational studies on the flat Ru(0001) surface and more realistic Ru surfaces with step edges and terraces. The results for graphene-supported Ru10Hx particles indicate that a model of the Ru/C catalyst with explicit hydrogens chemisorbed on the surface of metallic nanoparticle is essential for a complete understanding of the DDO process. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Ruthenium Phenol Graphene support Density functional theory 1 Introduction Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), a bio-oil upgrading step using hydrogen gas as a reductant for oxygen removal, has attracted considerable attention in the past few years [1–3]. The crude bio-oil produced by biomass pyrolysis contains a large amount of highly oxygenated species and therefore it cannot be used as a transportation fuel due to a low heating value and low chemical stability [4]. A large effort has been devoted to catalyst development for the HDO of phenolic compounds (phenols, cresols and guaiacols), representing a major fraction of oxygen-containing lignin pyrolysis products [5]. Advanced pyrolysis processes such as formate-assisted pyrolysis resulting in a very low oxygen content also lead to bio-oils rich in substituted phenols [6] . Conventional hydrotreating catalysts (CoMo and NiMo sulfides) suffer from low HDO activity, sulfur contamination and fast catalyst deactivation [7,8]. Recent HDO studies have mainly focused on a wide variety of supported metal and non- metal (phosphide and carbide) nanoparticles having higher activity at moderate reaction conditions [9]. The HDO activity and selectivity depend on the physical properties and composition of both the catalyst and the support. The apparent order of the carbon-supported noble metal activity for deoxygenation, Ru/C>Pd/C>Pt/C, has been related to metal affinity to bind oxygen [10] . Similarly, the HDO of m-cresol over silica-supported Pt and Ru catalysts leads to very different product distributions [11]. The role of the support is also important. For instance, the zirconia morphology significantly affects the HDO activity and selectivity to deoxygenated products during the HDO of phenol over a Pd/ZrO2 catalyst [12] . The Ru nanoparticle catalysts on various reducible (titania, zirconia) and non-reducible (carbon, silica, alumina) supports have been thoroughly evaluated for HDO activity using phenols as model compounds [5,13,14]. From a mechanistic point of view, there are two HDO pathways described in the literature: hydrogen-efficient direct deoxygenation (DDO) and hydrogenation followed by dehydration (HYD) [15,16]. The DDO/HYD ratio determines the overall hydrogen consumption of the HDO process. While the DDO mechanism on reducible supports involving a strong interaction of the phenol hydroxyl group with Lewis acid sites on the supports is relatively well understood, the role of non- reducible (chemically inactive) supports such as carbon or silica remains unclear. Investigations of the HDO of guaiacol over carbon-supported Ru nanoparticles have shown that the HDO selectivity strongly depends on the hydrogen pressure applied [13,17,18]. The deep deoxygenation to benzene occurs at moderate pressures of about 40bar with metallic ruthenium being reported as the active phase for complete oxygen removal [17]. Experiments using Ru nanoparticle catalysts on various supports have shown, however, different HDO product distributions [14]. DFT calculations on the HDO of phenolic compounds over Ru model surfaces have suggested that further deoxygenation of phenol to benzene over Ru(0001) catalysts is kinetically challenging [19,20]. The high barrier for the CO cleavage of phenolate (∼2eV) has been found to be in accord with experiments at low hydrogen pressures, which yield phenol as the main product of HDO over Ru/C [13,18,21]. Therefore, the aromatic-ring hydrogenation (HYD) pathway should be preferred on aggregated particles of calcined Ru catalysts. Large Ru particles on any support strongly interact with the aromatic ring and facilitate hydrogenation, whereas small Ru particles create a bifunctional catalyst with oxophilic supports [14,22]. The direct CO cleavage pathway cannot be ruled out for Ru/C catalysts either. The mechanistic details of phenol-to-benzene conversion have been investigated using slab models with step sites constructed by cutting the Ru bulk perpendicular to the [1015] direction [23]. The DFT activation barrier for the CO cleavage at step sites of the Ru catalyst has been found to be significantly lower (0.8eV), indicating that the DDO can be competitive with the HYD pathway. The DFT activation barriers for the respective HDO pathways have been evaluated using catalytic models without considering explicit adsorbed hydrogens (bare metal particle models). The corresponding HDO experiments have been carried out at elevated pressures of hydrogen (∼40bar), which makes the validity of such models questionable. DFT and experimental studies of hydrogen chemisorption on supported Ru nanoparticles are scarce [24,25] . The adsorption of 2 H per surface Ru atom has been reported for silica-supported Ru nanoparticles (2nm), a coverage much larger than observed for Ru(0001) surfaces [26,27]. A DFT study of hydrogen adsorption on the Ru10/TiO2 and Ru10/ZrO2 catalysts has estimated the saturation coverage on a metal cluster when spontaneous spillover of hydrogen atoms to the oxide surface becomes thermodynamically favorable. The spillover starts at coverages of about 2 and 3 H per surface Ru for Ru10/TiO2 and Ru10/ZrO2, respectively [25]. In the present study, carbon-supported Ru nanoclusters were investigated by means of periodic DFT calculations. Pristine and defected graphene structures were used as models for a chemically inactive carbon support. As compared to acidic supports, carbon-supported metal particle catalysts were reported to exhibit a much higher stability in the HDO of phenolic compounds [28]. Previous computational studies neglected the role of non-reducible supports, assuming that the HDO process took place solely on the metal catalyst [23]. In this work, we address several important issues related to these catalytic systems: (i) whether structural defects in carbon support can play the role of oxophilic sites similar to oxygen vacancies of the Ru/TiO2 and Ru/ZrO2 catalysts, (ii) whether the oxophilicity of Ru nanoparticles is sufficient to facilitate the DDO pathway, and (iii) what the effect of the hydrogen coverage of the metal catalyst on the activation barriers of the respective HDO processes is. 2 Methods 2.1 Models of the Ru/C catalyst Two models of the ruthenium catalyst deposited on graphene have been investigated: the Ru10 cluster and the periodic Ru bilayer (Fig. 1 ). The small Ru10 cluster model was built from the hcp phase of bulk Ru with a hexagonal base consisting of seven Ru atoms and three additional atoms situated on the top of the base. The Ru10 particle was deposited on a hexagonal graphene supercell (a = b = 12.324Å) containing 50 carbon atoms with 15Å vacuum between the graphene layers. The Ru catalyst was modeled as a bare metal particle and as Ru10Hx particles with hydrogen coverages corresponding to H/Ru(surface) ratios of 1:1 and 2:1. The following arrangements of chemisorbed hydrogens were explored for the Ru10H9 (1:1) particle: H atoms placed on top of each surface Ru atom and over RuRu bonds. The initial structure of Ru10H18 (2:1) comprised hydrogens placed over RuRu bonds and three H atoms attached to the upper Ru atoms. Two types of phenol–Ru10 complexes were considered: (i) the aromatic ring of phenol interacting with triangular and square faces of the metal particle, denoted as RuC complexes, and (ii) the oxygen of phenol bound to a single Ru atom either from the top or bottom layer, denoted as RuO complexes. The initial orientations of the phenol on Ru10Hx (x=9,18) particles were taken from the most stable structures (RuC and RuO complexes) of the bare particle model. The geometries of all optimized structures can be found in the Supplementary material. The periodic Ru bilayer (see Fig. 1b) has been chosen as a model of the interface between graphene and large Ru particles. This model is a periodic extension of the Ru10 particle with the top and bottom layers consisting of two and three rows of Ru atoms, respectively. The intralayer RuRu distances were set to 2.6Å and the CC bonds of graphene were slightly adjusted to accommodate the Ru bilayer model. An orthorhombic unit cell (a = 17.253Å b = 13.000Å) with graphene-layer separation of 15Å containing 84 carbon atoms and 25 Ru atoms (15 atoms in the bottom and 10 atoms in the top layer) was used. The Ru bilayer deposited on graphene is propagated in the b-direction. The unit-cell parameter a was chosen to ensure that the phenol molecules would not interact with periodic images of the Ru bilayer. 2.2 Computational details The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhoff (PBE) density functional [29] corrected for non-local electron correlation effects with the Grimme’s D3 dispersion term [30] was employed in periodic spin-polarized DFT calculations using the projector augmented- wave (PAW) method [31]. The energy cut-off was set to 400eV throughout this study. The Γ-point sampling of the Brillouin zone was used for structure optimization with the gradient convergence criterion below 10−2 eV/Å. The final interaction energies were obtained with 4×4×1 Γ-centered k-point sampling on the pre-optimized structures. These settings had been found to be sufficient for obtaining fully converged results in our previous studies on graphene-supported metal clusters [32]. The reported interaction energies have been calculated as E int = E Ph−Ru/G r − E Ru/Gr − E Ph, where E Ph−Ru/Gr is the total energy of the adsorbed phenol on the graphene-supported Ru particle, E Ru/Gr is the total energy of the optimized structure of the Ru cluster or the periodic Ru bilayer model (including hydrogen atoms) on graphene, and E Ph is the total energy of the optimized phenol molecule in the gas phase. The transition states (TS) were located using the nudge elastic band method [33,34] with four intermediate images and the improved dimer algorithm [35]. The TS structures were confirmed by frequency calculations. All the calculations were performed using the VASP (ver. 5.3.5) simulation package [36]. 3 Results and discussion Periodic DFT calculations on phenol interacting with graphene-supported Ru nanoparticles covered by chemisorbed hydrogen (0, 1 and 2 H per surface Ru atom) have been carried out to propose a mechanism for the DDO pathway over the Ru/C catalyst converting phenol to benzene and water without further hydrogenation of its aromatic ring. The calculated interaction energies and activation barriers for the CO scission process have been compared with the results of previous computational studies on flat Ru(0001) surfaces and Ru surfaces with edges and terraces. 3.1 DDO of phenol over Ru/graphene To approach the DDO mechanism over the Ru/C catalyst systematically, we explored the potential energy surface (PES) of the phenol–Ru10/graphene system. The most stable structures of RuC (I C–IV C) and RuO (V O and VI O) complexes are listed in Table 1 along with geometry parameters, and interaction and phenol deformation energies calculated at the PBE-D3 level of theory. We have found that carbon atoms in the phenol aromatic ring exhibit a strong preference for binding either to the triangular or square faces of the Ru10 particle. Interestingly, there is also a preference for the Ru/C interface (cf. interface structures I C, II C and IV C with structure III C in Table 1). A comparison of PBE interaction energies, i.e. without a proper treatment of non- local electron correlation effects, indicates that this is mostly caused by dispersion interactions with a graphene support. As can be seen from Table 1, the most stable RuO complexes (structures V O and VI O, where phenol is bound to the Ru cluster via oxygen) have significantly lower binding and deformation energies than the structures bound via the carbon atoms of the aromatic ring, with the differences in interaction energies being larger than 1eV. It can be assumed that the CO scission process mediated by Ru particles proceeds through RuO rather than RuC complexes with the phenol aromatic ring firmly attached to the Ru surface, favoring the HYD pathway. Therefore, we investigated the DDO mechanism for structures V O and VI O in more detail. In the case of VI O, the process leads to a simple dissociation of a phenyl radical (leaving OH on the Ru cluster) with the activation energy of 1.7eV. Even though the activation energy is significantly lowered with respect to the free phenol molecule in the gas phase, this barrier is still too high. For structure V O, we located a transition state for the CO scission with the energy of 0.51eV (Fig. 2 ). The calculated barrier height is thus comparable with the value for Ru/TiO2, which has been reported to be one of the most efficient catalysts for the DDO of phenol. The barrier separating V O and more stable II C is just 0.21eV, which makes the CO scission mechanism via structure V O less likely. It must be stressed, however, that only bare Ru particles without hydrogen have been considered as yet. As an alternative, we have investigated the situation where graphene defects substitute the role of Lewis active sites on reducible supports (e.g. Ti3+ sites on a TiO2 surface created by spillover of hydrogen in the vicinity of Ru nanoparticles). Graphene has edges with two different configurations, referred to as “armchair” and “zigzag” [37]. Missing or displaced lattice atoms create point defects. The role of both the point (single and double vacancies) and edge (armchair and zig-zag) defects has been investigated by means of DFT calculations. The PBE-D3 interaction energies for single and double vacancies are −2.5eV and −2.3eV, respectively. The largest contribution to the interaction energy is due to phenol interaction with the Ru10 particle and does not differ significantly from the pristine surface (cf. Table 1). Similar results have been obtained for complexes of phenol with graphene edges. The interaction energies for oxygen-bound complexes of phenol with armchair and zig-zag edges are 0.9eV and 0.4eV, respectively (more details can be found in the Supplementary material). It can be concluded that the CO bond of phenol is not activated enough by graphene defects, as a result of which the activation barrier for the CO scission is unrealistically large (>2eV) as compared to titania surfaces (0.4eV). Note that the reported activation barrier of 0.4eV has been calculated for the water-modified Ru/TiO2 model with oxygen vacancy [22]. It is also a question whether the defect sites (at least the edge sites) of the graphene layer do not get saturated by hydrogen under typical DDO reaction conditions. Hence, the corresponding DDO mechanism via a transition state where phenolic oxygen interacts with an oxophilic site on the graphene support and the aromatic ring is attached to a metal particle surface can be discarded. It is apparent from our PBE-D3 calculations that the CO scission reaction over Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C catalysts proceeds quite differently. The Ru10 cluster used as a model particle is fairly small when compared to the typical size of Ru particles in catalytic HDO. Therefore, we have investigated the phenol interaction with a periodic Ru bilayer on graphene to mimic the Ru/C interface of a more realistic Ru nanoparticle. Out of several optimizations, we have selected two structures as representative cases. The structure in Fig. 3 a is an oxygen-bound complex where the aromatic ring of phenol interacts with graphene (similar to structure V O in Table 1). The second structure (Fig. 3b) represents a case where both the aromatic ring and the oxygen atom of the adsorbed phenol molecule interact with the Ru nanoparticle and there is no significant interaction with the graphene support. This situation corresponds to recently reported results of a computational study on CO cleavage at Ru step sites [23]. The PBE-D3 interaction energies are −1.65eV and −3.03eV for the initial structures depicted in Figs. 3a and b, respectively. The barrier for the CO scission of the oxygen-bound complex is only 0.46eV. It is clear, however, that even a lower barrier can be found for transformation to a strongly bound RuC complex as discussed for the Ru10 model. The energy barrier in Fig. 3b (1.07eV) is almost twice as large due to a much larger energy penalty for the rearrangement of a strongly bound phenol molecule at the transition-state geometry. Also note that a lower barrier for the CO scission typically occurs in situations where the breaking of the CO bond is accompanied by the formation of new Ru-C bonds. This situation can be realized more easily when phenol is “climbing” on the Ru particle (see Fig. 3a). These findings are in a good accord with the results of previous theoretical studies on Ru(0001) and Ru surfaces with step sites [23]. The structure with the phenol molecule located on the top of the Ru bilayer (the RuC complex depicted in Fig. 3b) has the activation barrier for the CO scission of 1.07eV, which is slightly larger than the reported barrier for the Ru step site (0.8eV). Note, however, that the activation barrier on flat Ru surfaces is of about 2eV. On the other hand, the interface structure (the RuO complex depicted in Fig. 3a) has the activation barrier significantly smaller. Using a rather simplistic model (Fig. 3c), the hydrogenation barrier for RuC complexes was estimated to be around 1eV, which nearly coincides with the calculated barrier height for the CO scission process (1.07eV). Similar barriers for hydrogenation were also obtained in previous studies [22]. This clearly shows that even on bare Ru surfaces, the HYD pathway starts to compete with DDO. It should be emphasized, however, that the bare particle model is highly unrealistic under typical HDO reaction conditions (hydrogen pressure of approximately 40bar). An abundance of hydrogen on a catalytic particle will make the HYD pathway thermodynamically favorable. A similar effect has been observed for hydrogen spillover on reducible supports [25]. The calculated energy difference between the RuO and RuC complexes reported in Table 1 (>1eV) is probably too large for the oxygen-bound complexes to be actually formed on Ru particles. Since the RuC complexes (I C–IV C) prefer the HYD pathway over DDO, the results presented in Table 1 cannot actually explain the relatively large DDO activity for Ru/C catalysts observed in the experiments. In summary, we have found stable oxygen-bound complexes of phenol with reasonably low activation barriers of about 0.5eV for the CO scission process and consequently a possible DDO mechanism involving the breaking of the strong C(aryl)O bond without further saturation of the aromatic ring. The initial and transition states have been stabilized by dispersion interactions with the graphene support. The significant role of the Ru/graphene interface might explain the reported DDO activity of carbon- supported Ru catalysts [14]. Nevertheless, it is quite clear that the bare Ru particles will always prefer structures with phenol interacting via an aromatic ring (HYD intermediates), to which oxygen bound complexes (DDO intermediates) can be spontaneously transformed using pathways with negligible energy barriers. 3.2 DDO of phenol over Ru10Hx/graphene Most of the previous theoretical works on HDO have ignored the presence of hydrogen on the surfaces of model Ru catalysts, and therefore we find it worthwhile to investigate the properties of Ru10Hx particles. Two hydrogen coverages of the Ru10 particle have been used with H/Ru (surface) ratios of 1:1 and 2:1. The coverages of about 2 H per surface Ru atom reported for silica-supported Ru nanoparticles are close to the saturation limit at standard conditions (298K, 1bar) [24]. At elevated hydrogen pressures, coverages even larger than 2 H per surface Ru atom can be expected for small Ru nanoparticles (up to 2.25:1). On the other hand, structures with the H/Ru ratio of 3:1 used to emulate the spontaneous hydrogen spillover [25] are probably thermodynamically unstable at typical reaction conditions for the catalytic phenol conversion (573K, 45bar) [22]. The structure with 1 H per surface Ru atom is the preferred phase at very low hydrogen pressures (see Fig. 7 of Ref [24]). Hence, the Ru10H9 particles with the H/Ru ratio of 1:1 represent the low-pressure limit. The optimized structures of phenol-Ru10Hx (x=9,18) complexes are shown in Table 2 . When compared to bare Ru10 particles, the calculated PBE-D3 interaction energies are significantly smaller, with the most pronounced decrease found for RuC complexes (cf. Tables 1 and 2). As a result, the large energy difference between the most stable RuC (IV C) and RuO (V O) complexes of 1.5eV has completely disappeared for Ru10Hx particles. A brief inspection of Table 2 reveals that the differences in interaction energies become very small (below 0.1eV with the exception of dispersion-bound complexes, e.g. h– V C). For even larger H/Ru ratios, the RuO complexes might become energetically favorable. Nevertheless, the limiting factor at high hydrogen coverages is the barrier opposing hydrogen reorganizations on the surface of the metal particle required for the formation of the phenol-Ru10 complex. For the low-coverage limit (1:1), geometry optimizations of the initial structures with two different arrangements of adsorbed hydrogens on top of surface Ru atoms (top sites) and over RuRu bonds (bridge sites) lead to energetically very similar results for both RuC (h–I C and h–II C) and RuO (h–III O and h–IV O) complexes. The most stable arrangement of Ru10H9 with hydrogens located at bridge sites (h–II C and h–IV O) yields slightly less stable phenol-Ru10H9 complexes (by 0.1eV) as compared to structures with hydrogens situated at top sites (h–I C and h–III O). These observations clearly reflect the dynamic nature of the phenol adsorption process involving reorganizations of chemisorbed hydrogens. At higher pressures, structures with different hydrogen arrangements become separated by sizable energy barriers. There is also a barrier for phenol adsorption on the Ru10H18 particle. In the case of RuC complexes, the adsorption process starts with the formation of the dispersion- bound complex (h–V C) characterized by lower interaction energy and large RuC distances. The transition to a more stable structure (h–VI C) with much shorter RuC distances is accompanied by large displacements of hydrogen atoms (see Table 2). The calculated barrier height for this particular process is of about 0.3eV. In contrast, the formation of the RuO complex (h –VII O) does not require large hydrogen rearrangements upon adsorption. The summary of barrier heights for the CO scission reaction of phenol over Ru catalysts from various theoretical studies is given in Table 3 . Modeling the effect of hydrogen coverage of Ru nanoparticles on the CO scission barriers is quite complicated due to the fact that rearrangements of chemisorbed hydrogens are opposed by relatively low barriers, and therefore the scission process should be described dynamically. A single hydrogen atom influences the CO scission process only if it is bound to the Ru atom interacting directly with phenolic oxygen. In this case, the hydrogen atom slightly increases the CO scission barrier. The opposite effect was found for the phenol-Ru10H9/graphene complex where the CO scission barrier (0.33eV) is significantly lowered due to the presence of an activated Ru atom (see Supplementary data for more details). Based on our results we can conclude that the CO scission process depends on the hydrogen coverage in a rather complex fashion. These results obviously have important implications for the HDO mechanism as they negate at least some of the conclusions drawn from the bare-particle model of Ru catalysts. First, the presence of hydrogens evidently leads to significant changes in the relative stabilities of RuC and RuO complexes. This observation can easily be rationalized considering steric requirements of the respective structures. The RuO complex requires a space for only a single RuO bond. The energy penalty related to hydrogen reorganizations on the surface of metal particles is much larger for the RuC complexes that need to accommodate the aromatic ring of phenol (see Table 2). Second, it promotes the DDO pathway as the CO scission starts with the formation of a RuO(phenol) intermediate. The main drawback of bare-particle models for the DDO conversion of phenol to benzene is the instability of RuO complexes with respect to more stable RuC complexes. The hydrogens adsorbed on the surface of the metal particle not only stabilize the RuO complexes (or, more precisely, destabilize the RuC complexes), but they also create a barrier separating the RuO (DDO) and RuC (HYD) intermediates. The model of the Ru catalyst with explicit hydrogens thus seems to be essential for a complete understanding of the mechanistic details of DDO/HYD processes over a Ru/C catalyst. This conclusion is strictly valid only for the DDO/HYD processes on the surfaces of small (1–2nm) nanoparticles. The activation barriers previously reported for Ru(0001) and Ru- step-site models [19,20,23]. are likely to be less affected by neglecting chemisorbed hydrogens, because the Ru nanoparticles can adsorb significantly more hydrogen than ideal metallic surfaces. The reported binding energies for the 2:1 coverage (2 H atoms per Ru surface atom) are almost three times larger for the Ru55 hcp particle than for the flat Ru(0001) surface [24]. The activation barriers reported for reducible supports [22] can also be fairly unaffected since the actual CO scission process begins with phenol adsorption near an oxygen vacancy on a reducible support, and thus the corresponding activation barriers might be independent of the hydrogen coverage of the metal particle. 4 Conclusions DFT calculations on phenol interacting with graphene-supported Ru nanoparticles were carried out to propose a mechanism for the direct deoxygenation reaction over Ru/C catalysts. The CO scission process converting phenol to benzene and water without further hydrogenation of its aromatic ring was explored for three CO scission models: (i) the bare-particle model facilitating the DDO pathway via oxophilic Ru sites, (ii) a model with support defects playing the role of oxophilic sites similar to oxygen vacancies on reducible supports, and (iii) a realistic nanoparticle model including the effects of hydrogen coverage on the activation barriers of the respective HDO processes. The calculated interaction energies and activation barriers for the CO scission on the bare particle model of Ru/C catalysts are in good agreement with the results of previous computational studies on the flat Ru(0001) surface and more realistic Ru surfaces with step edges and terraces. The bare-particle model predicts stable oxygen-bound (RuO) complexes of phenol with reasonably low activation barriers for the CO scission of about 0.5eV. The initial and transition states are strongly stabilized by dispersion interactions with a graphene support in line with the reported DDO activity of carbon-supported Ru catalysts. The main drawback of the bare-particle model for the DDO pathway converting phenol to benzene and water is the instability of the RuO complexes with respect to the global minimum RuC structure with the energy difference of 1.5eV. Based on our PBE-D3 calculations, the DDO pathway with phenolic oxygen interacting with the defect sites of the graphene support (model (ii)) can be ruled out. The results obtained with more realistic Ru10Hx particles show that chemisorbed hydrogens on the surface of the metal nanoparticle stabilize the RuO complexes and create a barrier separating the RuO (DDO) and RuC (HYD) intermediates. It must be stressed, however, that the influence of the hydrogen coverage on the CO scission reaction is a non-trivial problem and should be dealt with by atomistic simulations at actual reaction conditions. The main results of this study can be summarized as follows: • Graphene defects in the vicinity of Ru particles are not catalytically active in the HDO process. • The CO scission of phenol on bare Ru nanoparticles can be promoted by a “climbing” mechanism at the Ru/C interface, which is energetically favorable due to the formation of new RuC bonds. • The model of graphene-supported Ru nanoparticles with explicit hydrogens on its surface is essential for a correct HDO assessment as the presence of hydrogens leads to profound changes in the relative stabilities of RuC and RuO complexes, as a result of which it significantly promotes the DDO pathway. These findings can easily be rationalized by the space requirements of RuC and RuO complexes. It is obviously much easier to create a single RuO bond on the surface of hydrogen-saturated Ru particles than to clear enough space for accommodating the aromatic ring especially at very high hydrogen pressures. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over graphene-supported Ru nanoparticles was investigated by means of periodic DFT calculations to propose a mechanism for the direct deoxygenation (DDO) pathway. The calculated interaction energies and activation barriers for the CO scission on bare particle models of Ru/C catalysts are in good agreement with previous computational studies on the flat Ru(0001) surface and more realistic Ru surfaces with step edges and terraces. The results for graphene-supported Ru10Hx particles indicate that a model of the Ru/C catalyst with explicit hydrogens chemisorbed on the surface of metallic nanoparticle is essential for a complete understanding of the DDO process.
coredata.dc:title: Direct hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over carbon-supported Ru catalysts: A computational study
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
